counters.title: Subjects

charts.description:
The ATLAS Knowledge Graph shows the diversity of Digital Humanities Research Products related to Italian Cultural Heritage. The largest share belongs to the artistic-literary domain — including Digital Scholarly Editions (33.33%), Text Collections (20.37%), and 3D Digital Twins (1.85%). The software field — Software (20.37%) and Language Models (1.85%) — also plays an important role, while the semantic web area — Linked Open Data (11.11%) and Ontology (7.41%) — contributes a relevant share. Smaller categories, grouped under Other (3.77%), reflect more niche directions.

This distribution highlights the richness and variety of DH research — for a clearer view, take a look at the chart on the side
charts.title: Research Products: different perspectives on Digital Cultural Heritage
Who shapes Italian Digital Humanities?
charts.description:
The most influential organizations involved in Italian Digital Cultural Heritage projects include universities (e.g., University of Bologna), research centres and labs (e.g., Visual Computing Lab), and public institutions (e.g., CNR, regional bodies like Regione Lombardia). Alongside them, private companies (e.g., NVIDIA Italy) and numerous international universities and labs (e.g., King’s Digital Lab) contribute, highlighting the collaborative and global nature of these projects.

This mix of organizations shows how Italian DH research connects institutions and scholars worldwide — explore the chart on the side
charts.query: PREFIX schema: <https://schema.org/> PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> SELECT ?organization (SAMPLE(?label) AS ?label) (COUNT(DISTINCT ?researchProduct) AS ?count) WHERE { ?researchProduct a schema:Dataset . { ?researchProduct ?p ?org . FILTER(?p IN (schema:contributor, schema:creator, schema:publisher)) ?org a schema:Organization ; rdfs:label ?label . BIND(?org AS ?organization) } UNION { ?researchProduct ?p ?member . FILTER(?p IN (schema:contributor, schema:creator, schema:publisher)) ?member schema:affiliation ?org . ?org a schema:Organization ; rdfs:label ?label . BIND(?org AS ?organization) } } GROUP BY ?organization ORDER BY DESC(?count) LIMIT 8

PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> SELECT ?geonames (SAMPLE(?label) AS ?label) (COUNT(DISTINCT ?geonames) AS ?count) WHERE { ?organization a <https://schema.org/Organization> . ?organization <https://schema.org/location> ?geonames . ?geonames rdfs:label ?label . } GROUP BY ?geonames ORDER BY ?geonames
charts.title: International scholarly research on Italian Digital Cultural Heritage
charts.description:
The geographical spread of cities involved in Italian Digital Cultural Heritage projects illustrates the global reach of these initiatives. While many activities are concentrated in Italy, researchers and institutions from around the world — including Brussels, Prague, Berlin, Baltimore, and London — also participate, highlighting the international nature of this research network.

Each city marks a point of engagement, showing both widespread involvement and concentrated regional activity. The map’s visual distribution emphasizes collaborative hubs and areas with high activity, making it easier to identify global trends in DH research.

This map highlights how Italian DH research connects cities worldwide — explore it on the side

Understanding how research unfolds in the Digital Humanities begins with documenting methodologies. TaDiRAH (Taxonomy of Digital Research Activities in the Humanities) helps classify these methods, making research more transparent and reproducible. This chart maps the most frequently used TaDiRAH terms, showing the distribution of key methodologies and highlighting both dominant and emerging research practices.
charts.title: Research patterns and Methodologies

charts.description:
Digital Humanities research on Italian cultural heritage continues to grow, with roughly one-third of research products still in development. Despite this, the field already counts a substantial number of completed works, some of which have set benchmarks for subsequent projects. Notable examples include the Codice Pelavicino Digital Edition and the software EVT, demonstrating excellence and serving as models for ongoing and future research.

The pie chart on the side shows the distribution of research products by creation status — completed versus in-progress
charts.title: Completed and Ongoing Research
Core Subjects of Italian Digital Cultural Heritage
charts.description:
This network highlights the most important Subjects extracted from the ATLAS Knowledge Graph, based on descriptions or the content of the Research Products. The chart on the side shows these central entities, which include Persons (e.g., Dante Alighieri), Places (e.g., Tuscany), Things (e.g., JSON and Web Ontology Language), and Creative Works (e.g., The Divine Comedy).

Explore the chart on the side to see the most central subjects in DH research
